>Actually I had another idea today whilst staring at a search that had
>stagnated...
>
>Looking at the list of species in SharpNEAT I could see that all species
>seemed to be stuck in a local peak in the fitness space. Now, when this
>happens species will arrive at the species droppoff age and will be
>dropped from the population. Eventually the number of species will drop
>below the minimum species threshold and so to compensate (this is
>SharpNEAT but I think this is close to other implementations) the genome
>compatibility threshold is lowered and this has the effect of splitting
>some species.
>
>Now this depends on the fitness space, but it seems to me that it's
>likely these new species will get stuck in the same local peaks,
>especially if they are very deep and/or broad, since they are spawned
>off of species that are already stuck. Thus I was thinking that a pool
>of dead species (or a token genome from each, say the species champ)
>could be kept and that we could implement some mechanism for avoiding
>the area of the fitness space represented by these genomes - using the
>genome compatibility function.
>
>I need to think through the specifics on this but it seems to make sense
>because it forces the search into new areas (or it could if implemented
>properly). The problem is how do we ensure we generate new genomes that
>are sufficiently different enough from the dead species to go and
>explore new areas of the search space? The answer may lie within the
>above discussion(s).

We (you don't know who) considered this years ago as part of searching 
protein folding configuration spaces (200+ dimensions) but we never tried it.

Call it an "Enforced Exploration" phase.

The idea was (this was in the context of steepest-descents or simulated 
annealing) to introduce an artificial force that drove the system away from 
one energy minimum (c.f. fitness peak).  We theorised that we would know 
when we had driven the system far enough, if when we released it, it did 
not fall back into the same optimum...

Of course, you could then chase the new optimum as far as was constructive, 
decide to drive away from it was well, and find you had got into a cycle 
where you ended up back in the original one.

BUT...

What if we kept exemplars of previous successful species in a list such as 
you were using for your TTT fitness assessments.  Then we could drive away 
from all of them during the EE-phase...

The other take I considered on the same thing was to wonder whether one 
could formulate a modification of the molecular energy function (c.f. 
fitness function) that would specifically remove one minimum (peak) from 
the landscape.  Obviously not in the general case but since we are 
designing that function ourselves...
